Rain Squelches Starlighter,
Mismanagement Charged

Rain put a damper on the
11-Club's annual Starlighter
Dance, held on the Gilman Terrace last Saturday evening.
"It was impossible to move the
dance to the gym," stated Chairman Sam Wright. "It took us twoand-one-half hours to set up the
dance, and when we set it up the
weather was good," he said. At
approximately 9 p.m., after showers interrupted the dance, the
band moved to the gym. Within
a half-hour the band had returned to the Keyser Quadrangle.
Rain Starts
Shortly after this, it again began to drizzle. After approximately an hour, the band,
squelched, left for good. Although
former H-Club President Richard
Watts refused to comment on the
situation, it was reported that the
band spent the rest of the evening in a fraternity house.
Chairman Wright stated that
money for the dance would not
be refunded, even though the
dance lasted only half the expected time. Wright explained that
the turnout for the dance was
greater than he had expected.
"I was surprised that the response
Was so great," he said."There were
approximately 500 couples there,
and not all had paid."
Nagler Comments

60TH YEAR

Josephs To Address
Graduation Exercise
Devereux C. Josephs, chairman of the board of the
New York Life Insurance Company, will deliver the commencement address at exercises marking the close of the 80th
academic year at The Johns Hopkins University, June
12,
at 10 a.m., on the Homewood campus.
A business executive, Mr. Josephs received his preparatory education at the Groton School and then attended
Harvard University. After receiving his bachelor's
in 1915, he entered the investment banking business degree
in Philadelphia with the firm of Graham, Parsons and
Company,
becoming a general partner in 1923.
He left the firm in 1939 to take
charge of the finances of a nuiiiber of Carnegie philanthropies.
The same year, Mr. Josephs was
elected financial vice-president of
the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association, founded by
Carnegie Corporation to institute
retirement plans for college
teachers.

Photo by Bachrach

D. C. JOSEPHS

SDA,Gather Money
For Bus Boycott
Johns Hopkins University Students for Democratic Action in
cooperation
other SDA
with
chapters throughout the country
is now collecting money to buy a
station wagon for the Negroes protesting bus segregation in Montgomery, Alabama.
Letters soliciting contributions
were sent to JHU-SDA's mailing
list, according to chapter chairman Ted Palmer, who will receive
contributions through Box 2304.
He said that the "goal of the
project was to buy a station wagon
or other vehicle to contribute to
the car pool."
"We feel," he stated, "that the
people in Montgomery who are
protesting the intolerably humiliating segregation practices enforced on their city busses deserve encouragement from Northern liberals."

ODK Initiates Eleven Students

Assumes Presidency
After serving as president of
the association for two years, he
assumed the presidency of the
Carnegie Corporation of New
York in 1945 and went from there
to the presidency of the New
York Life Insurance Company. In
1954, he became chairman of the
board of New York Life.
A director of J. P. Morgan and
Company, Inc., and Consolidated
Edison Company of New York, Mr.
Josephs is also a trustee of Johns
Hopkins University, Carnegie Corporation of New York, the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the New.
York Public Library, the Community Service Society and the Pierpont Morgan Library.
Active in civic enterprises, Mr.
Josephs was recently appointed by
President Eisenhower to head a
33 man committee on education
beyond the high school.

JHU Department
Gets Chairmanship
Filled By Edelman
By ALLAN MARKS
Dr. Nathan Edelman has accepted the Chairmanship of the
Romance Language Department of
the University, according to Dr.
G. Wilson Shaffer, dean of the
Homewood schools.
Dr. Edelman studied as an undergraduate at the College of the
City of New York, where he also
recevied his master's degree. He
completed his graduate training at
Columbia University.
Taught At Columbia
He has been an instructor in
French at CCNY, Hamilton College and Columbia, and in 1948
was named assistant professor of
French at Columbia. Later, he became associate professor in French
at the same university.
Among his administrative and
editorial experiences, Dr. Edelman was Departmental Head of
the French department at Columbia from 1952 to 1953, and was
managing editor of "The Romanic
Review" from 1948 to 1952.

Photo by Trimpi

Eleven men were inducted into Hopkins Beta Circle of Omicron Delta Kappa, the honorary activities fraternity, last Saturday. These men are, from left to right, Howard Waskow, John Rothney, Tom
Owens, Robert Knerr, Roger Kane, Jack Sutherland, Emily Muly, Aryln Marshall, Reid Gaskins, Lou
Dubilier (being pinned) and Paul Abrams. Assisting in the ceremony are James Pessin, Herbert Belgrad
(pinning), Dr. Lowell J. Reed, Mr. Albert Hutzler, Jr., Dr. W. K. Morrill, and Professor Thomas Hubbard. (See story on page 3.)

Editorial Jobs
He has been editor of the nation-wide project, "A Critical Bibliography of French Literature,"
Volume III, from 1953 to the present, and has occupied the position
of Assistant to the Dean at Columbia College since 1949.
Most of Dr. Edelman's publications have been published in "The
Romanic Review," although some
of them have appeared in the national publications: "The Word,"
"Symposium," "The Review of Religion," and "The French Review."

Cotillion Board Re-Initiates
Tryout System Next Fall
The Cotillion Board will initiate
an eight week tryout period in
September as a result of Student
Activities Commission suggestions
which were modified by the Board,
President Ron Nagler announced
this week.
Weekly meetings of the tryouts will be held "to keep up interest and to determine which try-

Honor Commission
Reminds Students
Of Test Behavior
"The Honor System has lasted
for 43 years here at Hopkins and
is one of the grand traditions
of the University. Please don't
abuse the privilege given to us,"
urged Porter Claxton, Honor Commission Chairman re-exams.
Speaking for the Commission,
Claxton stated: "Although it
should be unnecessary to remind
each student at this point in his
academic life that he is living
under an Honor System, we wish
to remind each student once
again as finals approach us."
Explained Claxton, "It will be
easy in the next two weeks while
under pressure .to forget for just
a moment that the Ho,nor Code
is still in force." He continued by
urging that every man here is a
man living by the Gentleman's
Code and that he should take care
that no suspicion fall upon him.
"It is a privilege to know that the
faculty and administration believe
that the students of this University are mature and honorable
enough to take an exam without
having proctors standing over
them like over children," summed
up Claxton.

outs show any ability." Also, tryouts will decorate and sell tickets
for only two dances, the Booster
Club prom and the Fall Cotillion.
Interview
An interview for final selection
of potential members will be held
on the afternoon of the Booster
dance, and the announcements of
the three new members will be
made that night.
In rebutting the SAC argument
that the entire system be abolished, Nagler said that there "is
a need for a try-out system to get
to know" the' potential members,
adding that "we can't rely on the
because we
interview system
haven't known the try-outs for a
long time."
Insinuations
He also said, "I doubt if there
will be any confusion concerning
ticket sales because tickets will be
sold for only two dances, and because there are meetings weekly."
"Try-outs will now be selected
before Pledge Sunday so there
will be no talk about the Cotillion
Board being a so-called fraternal
organization," the president said
when asked about the recent insinuations that the Board was under control of "fraternity politics."

Class Medallions
Given To Oldsters
Class Medallions were awarded
to the members of the class of
1906 on Homecoming Day last
Saturday, the presentations being
made by Hopkins President Lowell
J. Reed at the half-time of the
Hopkins-Maryland lacrosse game.
The class of 1906 consists of
29 members at present, 19 of
whom attended the Homecoming
ceremony.

Les Elgart and "The Band With
The Dancing Sound" will supply
the rhythm for the Senior Prom,
which will be held in the Alcazar
from 9 p.m. to 1 a.m. June 5.
Tickets for the dance will cost
$4. The price of the dance will be
included in the strip tickets which
are also on sale.
Having developed a style which
he calls "Sophisticated Swing,"
Elgart's band is one of the few
name bands in the country which
doesn't use a piano. Elgart chooses
to use the guitar extensively to
produce his "sound."
The present Les Elgart band was
organized only three years ago,
but since its conception, it has
acquired popularity rapidly within the college circuit. He has recently played at Ohio University,
Duke, Duquesne, Boston University, Connecticut, and Fordham.
Depending upon a saxaphone
played by Elgart's brother Larry,
the two-beat music is now the
trademark of the band. Its music
is arranged by Charles Albertine
and the band features vocalists
Don Forbes and Maurine White.
Elgart formerly was a featured
trumpet player with the Harry
James band.

Note Of Thanks
Dear Sirs:
We, the students who were involved through arrest at last Friday's pep rally, would like to give
special thanks to Dr. G. Wilson
Shaffer, dean of the Homewood
schools, for his contribution of
personal funds towards our bail,
and to Mr. Robert L. Strider, assistant plant manager, for his
direction of our release and bail
and for his consideration and reassurance throughout the entire
affair.
Also, we give heartfelt thanks
to Dr. Chester L. Wickwire, Executive Secretary of the Hopkins
'Y,' for his general assistance to
all the dormitory students who
contributed time, effort, and
money in our behalf.
The aid given by the Hopkins
community provided a strong reassurance that was deeply appreciated by all.
Respectfully yours,
Charles W. Casey
Alfred J. Cordes
Claude C. Gau
Edward F. Kammar, Jr.
Fred M. Menger
Donald A. Miller
David P. Schumacher
James H. Wheatcroft

Hopkins Film
Dear Sirs:
On Friday and Saturday last,
current and former members of
the Hopkins community were invited to view the results of a cinematic endeavor of our Public Relations Office to portray this University to the nation. That the
Product was a representation of
this institution could be discerned, not from the factual accuracy of the content, but rather
from the architectural resemblance between the site of the
drama and the Homewood camPus. It would appear that any
Other similarity was not by design, but purely coincidental.
Aside from the technical faults,
Which in themselves are gross
enough to warrant relegating the
entire strip to the cutting-room
floor, the film is guilty of only
one other crime—that of blatant misrepresentation. Presumably, one intention of this monstrous expenditure of scarce funds
is to recruit prospective students
and as such, the film ought to be
confiscated for wantonly luring

unsuspecting high school students
to an institution that is happily a
far cry from "The University" of
the photo-drama abomination perpetrated by the Public Relations
Office. The uproarious laughter
with which it was greeted, is indeed grim testimony to the obvious fraud. Derision is not an
unusual reaction to seeing one's
friends and associates in an obviously fictitious situation. To
very few in fact did the film picture the truth with which they
are familiar and of which they are
proud.
Futhermore, in attempting to
interest possible applicants for
admission, the film could only appeal to that variety of student who
would be better situated at an
institution more in keeping with
the country club atmosphere that

was created, rather than with the
commendable realities and potentialities of The Hopkins. The plain
and simple fact is that on no occasion throughout the entire duration of the trying theatrical was
Hopkins shown for what it is—an
institution of higher learning, of
creative scholarship and research,
of wholesome intellectual freedom.
There is no similarity between the
resort atmosphere of gaudy convertibles and vacations in the emerald green waters of Palm
Springs, and the sober realities of
diligent and proud academics for
which The Hopkins is world famous. The film, in short, was a
disgrace and ought forthwith to
be banned by the President from
any further showings.

What's doing
at Pratt & Whitney

—Orientation

The Original Wasp, the first P & W A engine — designed,
fabricated and assembled in less than seven months. Weighing under 650 pounds and officially rated at 410 horsepower, this lightweight, air-cooled radial engine was a
milestone in aviation history and set the pattern for almost
three decades of record-breaking advances.

Aircraft
Today's leadership .. . a
reflection of policies established
in aviation's infancy
Back in The Roaring Twenties, the magic dream pictured American families someday using the light personal airplane as freely as
the family car. Among the realists, however, was a handful of men
who were unshakable in their conviction that the real future of
aviation lay with bigger aircraft, higher speeds, greater ranges —
all possible only through engines of higher power and more reliability than those of that era.

The Double Wasp, an 18-cylinder, two-row piston engine
rated at 2400 horsepower for basic use. Its rating increased
by water injection to 3400 horsepower, the Double Wasp
was instrumental in turning many a military crisis into an
aerial victory in the decisive battles of World War II.

In the spring of 1925, six of these men of vision founded a
company in Hartford to undertake the development of a new aircraft engine — an air-cooled type. The year's end heralded their
first success — Pratt & Whitney Aircraft's "Wasp".
This talented group of men continued to improve their powerplant designs, developing engines of steadily mounting power that
operated efficiently and dependably. They contributed much to
aviation's progress — so much so that currently three-quarters of
the world's commercial airliners and many of our nation's first line
military aircraft are P & W A-powered.

The Wasp Major, a 28-cylinder engine with pistons arranged
in four rows of seven each and a 3800-horsepower rating.
Its power and performance having never been equalled, the
Wasp Major represents the apex of the art of building
reciprocating engines.

Today's P & W A powerplant designs are supported by the
very finest research facilities and equipment, and a technical staff
that is continually being strengthened. That nucleus of six men has
grown into one of the world's leadinz engineering organizations.
Yet to this very day, engineering achievement at Pratt & Whitney
Aircraft is guided by its founders' simple policy ... the best airplanes can be designed only around the best engines.

NEWS -LETTER

PAGE SIX

Successful Season
Seen By Bridgers
"This has been one of our most
successful seasons in many years
as far as dual meets are concerned," proudly exclaimed Hopkins track coach John Bridgers.
This was supported by the fact
that the varsity lost only one mee,t,
to the University of Delaware, and
that by a mere 3 points. They
Gettysburg,
wins over
claim
Swarthmore, Loyola, and Western Maryland.
The track season was climaxed
at Homewood with the MasonDixon Championship Meet. According to Bridgers,"We went into
the meet with a very well-balanced team and relatively few
outstanding performers." The results of the Mason-Dixon meet
showed this. Hopkins placed in 10
of a possible 14 events which was
more than any other team in
the Championships except Roanoke who won the tournament.
Many Hopkins men did well in
the Mason-Dixon Meet. Ray May
was tied for second place in the
pole vault and barely missed
breaking the Hopkins record.
Sandy Baklor threw the discus
further than he had ever thrown
before. He placed second with a
distance of 126 feet, 11 and :1 2
inches.
Caples, Heck Place
Robin Caples ran his best 440
yard dash in a time of 51.0 and
placed third. John Heck ran his
best times in the 100 and 220 yard
dashes with times of 10.0 and 23.2
respectively. He placed fourth in
a very close hundred and fifth in
the 220.
Jack Sutherland placed fourth
in one of the fastest half miles
ever run in the Mason-Dixon
tournament. Al Hlavin ran the low
hurdles in 15.9 seconds and placed
fourth and later on ran the high
hurdles in 25.8 seconds and placed
fifth. The mile relay placed fifth
with Wright and Caples running
good 440's.
The Mason-Dixon Tournament
at the Homewood this year was
the fastest meet ever run according to the Hopkins mentor. In 14
events, 7 records were broken.
Roanoke, Catholic University and
Johns Hopkins placed first, second and third respectively out of
a total of 13 teams entered in the
meet.
Heck Leads
Over the whole season, the
leading point scorer was John
Heck with a total of 531's points.
Following closely behind him were
Al Hlavin and Sam Wright with
50 and 48 1/3 points respectively.
Harry Close came close to break-

ing two Hopkins records. He
missed breaking th javelin record
by five inches and the high jump
record by 1V, inches.
When asked about the prospects
for next year coach Bridgers replied, "The prospects look good
next year with some of the freshmen coming up. The best performance of the year was 'by a
freshman. Morris 'Dusty' Jones
ran the mile in 4:36.9." Other
freshmen praised by the Hopkins
mentor were Claude Lindenberg,
who Bridgers said was "an excellent prospect in the high jump,"
Phil Holt in the sprints and distance men Gene Harshman and
Steve Scherping. The freshman
track squad ended the season with
a record of two wins and two defeats for a .500 season.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MAY 25, 1956

Jay Stickmen To Close Season
Against Mount Washington
Exploding to score three goals
in 48 seconds early in the fourth
quarter to build u1 an insurmountable lead, the 1956 National
Lacrosse Champions, Maryland,
scored their twenty-third consecutive victory at the expense of
the Hopkins Blue Jays at Homewood Field last Saturday.
Tomorrow the Jays will seek
the first Hopkins victory over the
Mount Washington Lacrosse Club
since 1941 in the final game of the
season fog the Jays. Pacing the
hosts will be several former Hopkins stickmen including former
All-American Jim Adams, Mort
Kalus, Jack Poholhaus, Ray Santamaris, Buzzy Budnitz, and the
Jays' varsity assistant coach Fred
Smith.
Last Saturday the undefeated
Terrapins sent the Jays down to
their third defeat of the season
and broke their six game winning
streak before 7,000 Homecoming
fans.
Jays Take Lead
Arlyn Marshall electrified the
partisan fans early in the initial
per-iod when he tallied his eighteenth goal of the season to give
the Jays a 1-0 lead. However, the
Terps bounced back to score four
times in the period while limiting
Hopkins to only one other goal
and led 4-2 as the first period
ended.
In the second period Carl Muly
bounced a goal past Maryland's
Jim Kappler to narrow the margin to 4-3 with only one minute
gone in the quarter. Frank Tamburello and Charlie Wicker scored
unassisted goals later in the period to give the visitors a 6-3 halftime lead.

WAVERLY'S NEWEST

After each team traded scores
early in the third quarter, George
Breslau fed Ned Turnbull, who
scored from in front of the goal
to cut the Terp lead to 7-5. Before the period had ended the
Terps had scored twice to lead
9-5 as the game entercd the final
quarter.
John Jory tallied on an assist
from Breslau after three minutes
were gone in the final period to
cut the Terp lead to 9-6. However,
Charlie Wicker scored twice within twenty seconds and the Terps
added another goal shortly to end
all hopes of another Jay victory.
Scott Praises Jays
Hopkins coach Bob Scott stated,
"We played aggressively, but their
ball control was just too much to
overcome. The boys fought hard
all the way and are to be commended for their spirit. I was satisfied with our performance, since
this was probably Maryland's best
collegiate performance of the season. Their speed, stickwork and
bench strength were those of a
true champ.
Scott praised his team for its
showing until early in the fourth
quarter when Maryland broke the
game open with three goals in 48
seconds.
"Our attack functioned fairly
well with each starter scoring
once," continued the Jay mentor. "Marshall's usual fine performance will rate him as one of

Division.
Marshall Paces Attack
Leading the Hopkins scorers
was Arlyn Marshall, who scored 19
goals and one assist. The other
leading scorers among the midfielders were Dave Collignon, seven goals and six assists, and Jerry
Bennet, who scored five goals and
assisted on eight other scores.
John Jory led the attackmen
with ten goals and 12 assists, while
George Breslau garnered seven
goals and eight assists. Ned Turnbull got six goals and two assists.
Chet Schmidt, senior midfielder,
was injured in an automobile accident and was unable to Pia/
against Maryland. His condition
is not serious and was expected
out of the hospital this past weelt.
Chet, according to Bob Scott, has
shown hustle and improvement in
his play during the past season.

Three seniors from the Hopkins lacrosse squad have been selected to play in the annual
North-South lacrosse game at
Geneva, New York on June 9.
Representing Hopkins will be
Arlyn Marshall, Dick Watts and
Bob Burgess, all of whom will
finish their college stick careers
Saturday against Mt. Washington.
Marshall has been praised by
his coach, Bob Scott, throughout
the season for hustle, leadership
and scoring ability. Scott rates
him as one of the most outstanding midfielders in the nation.
Burgess and Watts have combined with Walt Mitchell and Don
Gallagher to give the Jays a defense that has allowed its opponents an average of only seven
goals per game.

score, the winning run coming on
a steal of home in the twelfth
inning. Sachs conisdered this the
type of mistake that has cost Hopkins ball games.

limited success. Frank Hyde, in

What young people are doing at General Electric
• Pg'OERf.

;•-••-;

Young ad man
handles GE jet
and rocket engine
advertising
The first jet engine ever to power an American plane was built by General Electric in
1942. Since 1948, G.E. has supplied the Air
Force with over 30,000 of its famous J47
jet engines. And General Electric's jet ex-perience soon will be paying additional new
dividends to national defense. Its J79 —
called the most advanced engine of its type
in the world—will soon enter production.
The man responsible for reporting G.E.'s
jet and rocket engine progress to its customers and the public is Roy 0.Stratton, Jr.,
27-year-old account supervisor in the Company's Apparatus Advertising and Sales
Promotion Department.
Stratton's Work Important, Interesting
Stratton supervises the planning and preparation of direct-mail promotion, brochures,
films and presentations, as well as publicinformationalspace advertisements for Time,
U.S. News & World Report, Business Week,
• . Aviation Week, and other magazines.
Considerable personal contact with the
Armed Services makes Stratton's job an interesting one. Last year he traveled over
60,000 miles, visiting many of the country's
Air Force bases to gather necessary information and pictures.
25,000 College Graduates at General Electric
When Stratton came to General Electric in
1952, he already knew the kind of work he
wanted to do. Like each of our 25,000 college graduates, he is being given the chance
to grow and realize his full potential. For
General Electric has long believed this: when
fresh young minds are given the freedom to
develop, everybody benefits—the individual,
the Company, and the country.
Educational Relations, General Electric
Company,Schenectady 5, New York

t'T

AFTER RECEIVING a B.A.
in English from Brown
University, Roy Stratton
joined G.E.in 1952 in the
Advertising and Public
Relations Training Program. He worked as instruction-book editor and
advertising copy writer
before his current job.

Rain Squelches Starlighter,
Mismanagement Charged

Rain put a damper on the
11-Club's annual Starlighter
Dance, held on the Gilman Terrace last Saturday evening.
"It was impossible to move the
dance to the gym," stated Chairman Sam Wright. "It took us twoand-one-half hours to set up the
dance, and when we set it up the
weather was good," he said. At
approximately 9 p.m., after showers interrupted the dance, the
band moved to the gym. Within
a half-hour the band had returned to the Keyser Quadrangle.
Rain Starts
Shortly after this, it again began to drizzle. After approximately an hour, the band,
squelched, left for good. Although
former H-Club President Richard
Watts refused to comment on the
situation, it was reported that the
band spent the rest of the evening in a fraternity house.
Chairman Wright stated that
money for the dance would not
be refunded, even though the
dance lasted only half the expected time. Wright explained that
the turnout for the dance was
greater than he had expected.
"I was surprised that the response
Was so great," he said."There were
approximately 500 couples there,
and not all had paid."

60TH YEAR

Josephs To Address
Graduation Exercise
Devereux C. Josephs, chairman of the board of the
New York Life Insurance Company, will deliver the commencement address at exercises marking the close of the 80th
academic year at The Johns Hopkins University, June
12,
at 10 a.m., on the Homewood campus.
A business executive, Mr. Josephs received his preparatory education at the Groton School and then attended
Harvard University. After receiving his bachelor's
in 1915, he entered the investment banking business degree
in Philadelphia with the firm of Graham, Parsons and
Company,
becoming a general partner in 1923.
He left the firm in 1939 to take
charge of the finances of a nuiiiber of Carnegie philanthropies.
The same year, Mr. Josephs was
elected financial vice-president of
the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association, founded by
Carnegie Corporation to institute
retirement plans for college
teachers.

Photo by Bachrach

D. C. JOSEPHS

SDA,Gather Money
For Bus Boycott
Johns Hopkins University Students for Democratic Action in
cooperation
other SDA
with
chapters throughout the country
is now collecting money to buy a
station wagon for the Negroes protesting bus segregation in Montgomery, Alabama.
Letters soliciting contributions
were sent to JHU-SDA's mailing
list, according to chapter chairman Ted Palmer, who will receive
contributions through Box 2304.
He said that the "goal of the
project was to buy a station wagon
or other vehicle to contribute to
the car pool."
"We feel," he stated, "that the
people in Montgomery who are
protesting the intolerably humiliating segregation practices enforced on their city busses deserve encouragement from Northern liberals."

ODK Initiates Eleven Students

Assumes Presidency
After serving as president of
the association for two years, he
assumed the presidency of the
Carnegie Corporation of New
York in 1945 and went from there
to the presidency of the New
York Life Insurance Company. In
1954, he became chairman of the
board of New York Life.
A director of J. P. Morgan and
Company, Inc., and Consolidated
Edison Company of New York, Mr.
Josephs is also a trustee of Johns
Hopkins University, Carnegie Corporation of New York, the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the New.
York Public Library, the Community Service Society and the Pierpont Morgan Library.
Active in civic enterprises, Mr.
Josephs was recently appointed by
President Eisenhower to head a
33 man committee on education
beyond the high school.

JHU Department
Gets Chairmanship
Filled By Edelman
By ALLAN MARKS
Dr. Nathan Edelman has accepted the Chairmanship of the
Romance Language Department of
the University, according to Dr.
G. Wilson Shaffer, dean of the
Homewood schools.
Dr. Edelman studied as an undergraduate at the College of the
City of New York, where he also
recevied his master's degree. He
completed his graduate training at
Columbia University.
Taught At Columbia
He has been an instructor in
French at CCNY, Hamilton College and Columbia, and in 1948
was named assistant professor of
French at Columbia. Later, he became associate professor in French
at the same university.
Among his administrative and
editorial experiences, Dr. Edelman was Departmental Head of
the French department at Columbia from 1952 to 1953, and was
managing editor of "The Romanic
Review" from 1948 to 1952.

Photo by Trimpi

Eleven men were inducted into Hopkins Beta Circle of Omicron Delta Kappa, the honorary activities fraternity, last Saturday. These men are, from left to right, Howard Waskow, John Rothney, Tom
Owens, Robert Knerr, Roger Kane, Jack Sutherland, Emily Muly, Aryln Marshall, Reid Gaskins, Lou
Dubilier (being pinned) and Paul Abrams. Assisting in the ceremony are James Pessin, Herbert Belgrad
(pinning), Dr. Lowell J. Reed, Mr. Albert Hutzler, Jr., Dr. W. K. Morrill, and Professor Thomas Hubbard. (See story on page 3.)

Editorial Jobs
He has been editor of the nation-wide project, "A Critical Bibliography of French Literature,"
Volume III, from 1953 to the present, and has occupied the position
of Assistant to the Dean at Columbia College since 1949.
Most of Dr. Edelman's publications have been published in "The
Romanic Review," although some
of them have appeared in the national publications: "The Word,"
"Symposium," "The Review of Religion," and "The French Review."

Cotillion Board Re-Initiates
Tryout System Next Fall
The Cotillion Board will initiate
an eight week tryout period in
September as a result of Student
Activities Commission suggestions
which were modified by the Board,
President Ron Nagler announced
this week.
Weekly meetings of the tryouts will be held "to keep up interest and to determine which try-

Honor Commission
Reminds Students
Of Test Behavior
"The Honor System has lasted
for 43 years here at Hopkins and
is one of the grand traditions
of the University. Please don't
abuse the privilege given to us,"
urged Porter Claxton, Honor Commission Chairman re-exams.
Speaking for the Commission,
Claxton stated: "Although it
should be unnecessary to remind
each student at this point in his
academic life that he is living
under an Honor System, we wish
to remind each student once
again as finals approach us."
Explained Claxton, "It will be
easy in the next two weeks while
under pressure .to forget for just
a moment that the Ho,nor Code
is still in force." He continued by
urging that every man here is a
man living by the Gentleman's
Code and that he should take care
that no suspicion fall upon him.
"It is a privilege to know that the
faculty and administration believe
that the students of this University are mature and honorable
enough to take an exam without
having proctors standing over
them like over children," summed
up Claxton.

Les Elgart and "The Band With
The Dancing Sound" will supply
the rhythm for the Senior Prom,
which will be held in the Alcazar
from 9 p.m. to 1 a.m. June 5.
Tickets for the dance will cost
$4. The price of the dance will be
included in the strip tickets which
are also on sale.
Having developed a style which
he calls "Sophisticated Swing,"
Elgart's band is one of the few
name bands in the country which
doesn't use a piano. Elgart chooses
to use the guitar extensively to
produce his "sound."
The present Les Elgart band was
organized only three years ago,
but since its conception, it has
acquired popularity rapidly within the college circuit. He has recently played at Ohio University,
Duke, Duquesne, Boston University, Connecticut, and Fordham.
Depending upon a saxaphone
played by Elgart's brother Larry,
the two-beat music is now the
trademark of the band. Its music
is arranged by Charles Albertine
and the band features vocalists
Don Forbes and Maurine White.
Elgart formerly was a featured
trumpet player with the Harry
James band.

Note Of Thanks
Dear Sirs:
We, the students who were involved through arrest at last Friday's pep rally, would like to give
special thanks to Dr. G. Wilson
Shaffer, dean of the Homewood
schools, for his contribution of
personal funds towards our bail,
and to Mr. Robert L. Strider, assistant plant manager, for his
direction of our release and bail
and for his consideration and reassurance throughout the entire
affair.
Also, we give heartfelt thanks
to Dr. Chester L. Wickwire, Executive Secretary of the Hopkins
'Y,' for his general assistance to
all the dormitory students who
contributed time, effort, and
money in our behalf.
The aid given by the Hopkins
community provided a strong reassurance that was deeply appreciated by all.
Respectfully yours,
Charles W. Casey

Hopkins Film
Dear Sirs:
On Friday and Saturday last,
current and former members of
the Hopkins community were invited to view the results of a cinematic endeavor of our Public Relations Office to portray this University to the nation. That the
Product was a representation of
this institution could be discerned, not from the factual accuracy of the content, but rather
from the architectural resemblance between the site of the
drama and the Homewood camPus. It would appear that any
Other similarity was not by design, but purely coincidental.
Aside from the technical faults,
Which in themselves are gross
enough to warrant relegating the
entire strip to the cutting-room
floor, the film is guilty of only
one other crime—that of blatant misrepresentation. Presumably, one intention of this monstrous expenditure of scarce funds
is to recruit prospective students
and as such, the film ought to be
confiscated for wantonly luring

unsuspecting high school students
to an institution that is happily a
far cry from "The University" of
the photo-drama abomination perpetrated by the Public Relations
Office. The uproarious laughter
with which it was greeted, is indeed grim testimony to the obvious fraud. Derision is not an
unusual reaction to seeing one's
friends and associates in an obviously fictitious situation. To
very few in fact did the film picture the truth with which they
are familiar and of which they are
proud.
Futhermore, in attempting to
interest possible applicants for
admission, the film could only appeal to that variety of student who
would be better situated at an
institution more in keeping with
the country club atmosphere that

was created, rather than with the
commendable realities and potentialities of The Hopkins. The plain
and simple fact is that on no occasion throughout the entire duration of the trying theatrical was
Hopkins shown for what it is—an
institution of higher learning, of
creative scholarship and research,
of wholesome intellectual freedom.
There is no similarity between the
resort atmosphere of gaudy convertibles and vacations in the emerald green waters of Palm
Springs, and the sober realities of
diligent and proud academics for
which The Hopkins is world famous. The film, in short, was a
disgrace and ought forthwith to
be banned by the President from
any further showings.

What's doing
at Pratt & Whitney

—Orientation

The Original Wasp, the first P & W A engine — designed,
fabricated and assembled in less than seven months. Weighing under 650 pounds and officially rated at 410 horsepower, this lightweight, air-cooled radial engine was a
milestone in aviation history and set the pattern for almost
three decades of record-breaking advances.

Aircraft
Today's leadership .. . a
reflection of policies established
in aviation's infancy
Back in The Roaring Twenties, the magic dream pictured American families someday using the light personal airplane as freely as
the family car. Among the realists, however, was a handful of men
who were unshakable in their conviction that the real future of
aviation lay with bigger aircraft, higher speeds, greater ranges —
all possible only through engines of higher power and more reliability than those of that era.

The Double Wasp, an 18-cylinder, two-row piston engine
rated at 2400 horsepower for basic use. Its rating increased
by water injection to 3400 horsepower, the Double Wasp
was instrumental in turning many a military crisis into an
aerial victory in the decisive battles of World War II.

In the spring of 1925, six of these men of vision founded a
company in Hartford to undertake the development of a new aircraft engine — an air-cooled type. The year's end heralded their
first success — Pratt & Whitney Aircraft's "Wasp".
This talented group of men continued to improve their powerplant designs, developing engines of steadily mounting power that
operated efficiently and dependably. They contributed much to
aviation's progress — so much so that currently three-quarters of
the world's commercial airliners and many of our nation's first line
military aircraft are P & W A-powered.

The Wasp Major, a 28-cylinder engine with pistons arranged
in four rows of seven each and a 3800-horsepower rating.
Its power and performance having never been equalled, the
Wasp Major represents the apex of the art of building
reciprocating engines.

Today's P & W A powerplant designs are supported by the
very finest research facilities and equipment, and a technical staff
that is continually being strengthened. That nucleus of six men has
grown into one of the world's leadinz engineering organizations.
Yet to this very day, engineering achievement at Pratt & Whitney
Aircraft is guided by its founders' simple policy ... the best airplanes can be designed only around the best engines.

NEWS -LETTER

PAGE SIX

Successful Season
Seen By Bridgers
"This has been one of our most
successful seasons in many years
as far as dual meets are concerned," proudly exclaimed Hopkins track coach John Bridgers.
This was supported by the fact
that the varsity lost only one mee,t,
to the University of Delaware, and
that by a mere 3 points. They
Gettysburg,
wins over
claim
Swarthmore, Loyola, and Western Maryland.
The track season was climaxed
at Homewood with the MasonDixon Championship Meet. According to Bridgers,"We went into
the meet with a very well-balanced team and relatively few
outstanding performers." The results of the Mason-Dixon meet
showed this. Hopkins placed in 10
of a possible 14 events which was
more than any other team in
the Championships except Roanoke who won the tournament.
Many Hopkins men did well in
the Mason-Dixon Meet. Ray May
was tied for second place in the
pole vault and barely missed
breaking the Hopkins record.
Sandy Baklor threw the discus
further than he had ever thrown
before. He placed second with a
distance of 126 feet, 11 and :1 2
inches.
Caples, Heck Place
Robin Caples ran his best 440
yard dash in a time of 51.0 and
placed third. John Heck ran his
best times in the 100 and 220 yard
dashes with times of 10.0 and 23.2
respectively. He placed fourth in
a very close hundred and fifth in
the 220.
Jack Sutherland placed fourth
in one of the fastest half miles
ever run in the Mason-Dixon
tournament. Al Hlavin ran the low
hurdles in 15.9 seconds and placed
fourth and later on ran the high
hurdles in 25.8 seconds and placed
fifth. The mile relay placed fifth
with Wright and Caples running
good 440's.
The Mason-Dixon Tournament
at the Homewood this year was
the fastest meet ever run according to the Hopkins mentor. In 14
events, 7 records were broken.
Roanoke, Catholic University and
Johns Hopkins placed first, second and third respectively out of
a total of 13 teams entered in the
meet.
Heck Leads
Over the whole season, the
leading point scorer was John
Heck with a total of 531's points.
Following closely behind him were
Al Hlavin and Sam Wright with
50 and 48 1/3 points respectively.
Harry Close came close to break-

ing two Hopkins records. He
missed breaking th javelin record
by five inches and the high jump
record by 1V, inches.
When asked about the prospects
for next year coach Bridgers replied, "The prospects look good
next year with some of the freshmen coming up. The best performance of the year was 'by a
freshman. Morris 'Dusty' Jones
ran the mile in 4:36.9." Other
freshmen praised by the Hopkins
mentor were Claude Lindenberg,
who Bridgers said was "an excellent prospect in the high jump,"
Phil Holt in the sprints and distance men Gene Harshman and
Steve Scherping. The freshman
track squad ended the season with

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MAY 25, 1956

Jay Stickmen To Close Season
Against Mount Washington
Exploding to score three goals
in 48 seconds early in the fourth
quarter to build u1 an insurmountable lead, the 1956 National
Lacrosse Champions, Maryland,
scored their twenty-third consecutive victory at the expense of
the Hopkins Blue Jays at Homewood Field last Saturday.
Tomorrow the Jays will seek
the first Hopkins victory over the
Mount Washington Lacrosse Club
since 1941 in the final game of the
season fog the Jays. Pacing the
hosts will be several former Hopkins stickmen including former
All-American Jim Adams, Mort
Kalus, Jack Poholhaus, Ray Santamaris, Buzzy Budnitz, and the
Jays' varsity assistant coach Fred
Smith.
Last Saturday the undefeated
Terrapins sent the Jays down to
their third defeat of the season
and broke their six game winning
streak before 7,000 Homecoming
fans.
Jays Take Lead
Arlyn Marshall electrified the
partisan fans early in the initial
per-iod when he tallied his eighteenth goal of the season to give
the Jays a 1-0 lead. However, the
Terps bounced back to score four
times in the period while limiting
Hopkins to only one other goal
and led 4-2 as the first period
ended.
In the second period Carl Muly
bounced a goal past Maryland's
Jim Kappler to narrow the margin to 4-3 with only one minute
gone in the quarter. Frank Tamburello and Charlie Wicker scored
unassisted goals later in the period to give the visitors a 6-3 halftime lead.

WAVERLY'S NEWEST

After each team traded scores
early in the third quarter, George
Breslau fed Ned Turnbull, who
scored from in front of the goal
to cut the Terp lead to 7-5. Before the period had ended the
Terps had scored twice to lead
9-5 as the game entercd the final
quarter.
John Jory tallied on an assist
from Breslau after three minutes
were gone in the final period to
cut the Terp lead to 9-6. However,
Charlie Wicker scored twice within twenty seconds and the Terps
added another goal shortly to end
all hopes of another Jay victory.
Scott Praises Jays
Hopkins coach Bob Scott stated,
"We played aggressively, but their
ball control was just too much to
overcome. The boys fought hard
all the way and are to be commended for their spirit. I was satisfied with our performance, since
this was probably Maryland's best
collegiate performance of the season. Their speed, stickwork and
bench strength were those of a
true champ.
Scott praised his team for its
showing until early in the fourth
quarter when Maryland broke the
game open with three goals in 48
seconds.
"Our attack functioned fairly
well with each starter scoring
once," continued the Jay mentor. "Marshall's usual fine performance will rate him as one of

Division.
Marshall Paces Attack
Leading the Hopkins scorers
was Arlyn Marshall, who scored 19
goals and one assist. The other
leading scorers among the midfielders were Dave Collignon, seven goals and six assists, and Jerry
Bennet, who scored five goals and
assisted on eight other scores.
John Jory led the attackmen
with ten goals and 12 assists, while
George Breslau garnered seven
goals and eight assists. Ned Turnbull got six goals and two assists.
Chet Schmidt, senior midfielder,
was injured in an automobile accident and was unable to Pia/
against Maryland. His condition
is not serious and was expected
out of the hospital this past weelt.
Chet, according to Bob Scott, has
shown hustle and improvement in
his play during the past season.

Turner Announces
Change In Service
Athletic Director Marshall S.
Turner has announced that there
will be a change in the inner
gear service beginning in the fall.

worked out, the essence of the
new plan is that students who use
the inner gear service will be required to purchase the inner gear
card at the beginning of the school
year at a pre-set price. In the
past students have been billed at
the end of the year for the service.

that, because of the 4igh number
of lost cards this year, there will
be an attempt to affix some sort
of penalty for the loss of the
card in the future.

What young people are doing at General Electric
• Pg'OERf.

;•-••-;

Young ad man
handles GE jet
and rocket engine
advertising
The first jet engine ever to power an American plane was built by General Electric in
1942. Since 1948, G.E. has supplied the Air
Force with over 30,000 of its famous J47
jet engines. And General Electric's jet ex-perience soon will be paying additional new
dividends to national defense. Its J79 —
called the most advanced engine of its type
in the world—will soon enter production.
The man responsible for reporting G.E.'s
jet and rocket engine progress to its customers and the public is Roy 0.Stratton, Jr.,
27-year-old account supervisor in the Company's Apparatus Advertising and Sales
Promotion Department.
Stratton's Work Important, Interesting
Stratton supervises the planning and preparation of direct-mail promotion, brochures,
films and presentations, as well as publicinformationalspace advertisements for Time,
U.S. News & World Report, Business Week,
• . Aviation Week, and other magazines.
Considerable personal contact with the
Armed Services makes Stratton's job an interesting one. Last year he traveled over
60,000 miles, visiting many of the country's
Air Force bases to gather necessary information and pictures.
25,000 College Graduates at General Electric
When Stratton came to General Electric in
1952, he already knew the kind of work he
wanted to do. Like each of our 25,000 college graduates, he is being given the chance
to grow and realize his full potential. For
General Electric has long believed this: when
fresh young minds are given the freedom to
develop, everybody benefits—the individual,
the Company, and the country.
Educational Relations, General Electric
Company,Schenectady 5, New York

t'T

AFTER RECEIVING a B.A.
in English from Brown
University, Roy Stratton
joined G.E.in 1952 in the
Advertising and Public
Relations Training Program. He worked as instruction-book editor and
advertising copy writer
before his current job.
